plist.p: Okay, good morning, everyone. Welcome to our results presentation and especially welcome to Philip, our new CEO and his first results, which I believe are a good set of results. Phil, we all wish you well, not only today, but also going forward as our leader. On the presentations today, Philip will go first; followed by Laurie; and I'll then chair the Q&A and obviously Steve Webb will be with us throughout. So can I introduce Phil?

Thank you. Well, thanks, David, and good morning, everyone. We're going to do things a little bit differently this morning. I'm going to start the meeting today, not much with an update, although Laurie and I will do that, too. Instead, I'm going to talk about how I see the business as the new CEO and what our immediate objectives are.

For those of you who don't know me, I've been with Tesco for quite a long time now, over 35 years, and I've worked in most parts of the business, in stores, in commercial, in marketing and in supply chain. And until I got the call from David to say that I was to succeed Terry last year, I'd been running Asia, Europe and IT (1:17) for eight years. So I'm used to running big businesses and large teams, but first and foremost I'm a retailer.

And Tesco is a really great business. It's built around customers, it's built around staff, with very high quality assets around the world and multiple opportunities for growth. I think that's a pretty good platform on which to start. And my job is to build on that for all of our stakeholders, but most importantly for our shareholders.

You'll mostly see continuity, because the strategy is a good one, because we've got a strong team and because we think the period of highest risk in the diversification of Tesco is now behind us. But there will also be change. There will be change because we know we can do some things better and because as customers change so must Tesco. We made a start and there will be more to come. The new management structures are in place and they're about equipping the group for global growth. That means the big driving business units of the U.K., Asia, Europe, America, Services and Property will be supported by integrating functions, such as brand marketing, grouped buying, IT, finance and personnel, so that we leverage the skill and the scale of the group. And my new executive team brings that all together.

I believe Tesco has reached the point in its development where it's the right time to move to the matrix approach that the FMCG (2:57) companies have adopted, so that we're ready for the next phase of our development. And that's why we've done it. The biggest part of the change is in the U.K. It's now got its own Board and it's bringing more focus and energy to our largest business. But of course structures don't manage companies, people do, and looking at the U.K. as an example, we put a very strong team in under Richard Brasher, and have taken the opportunity to bring some of our best, some of our most experienced general managers who've done senior jobs internationally back to the U.K. There could be no better demonstration of the depth of talent across the Tesco Group.

This brings me on to the C – six key objectives I've set for the business. I'm going to return to them regularly in these meetings, because they're what I expect to be judged on. The first one of these is keeping the U.K. strong and growing. It's top of the list. Second, we want Tesco to be outstanding internationally, not just successful. Third, and as the combination of stores and online becomes compelling for customers, we aim to become a multi-channel retailer wherever we trade. Fourth, we will deliver on the potential of Retailing Services, of which the bank is a very big part. Fifth, by applying group skill and scale, we can add even more value and competitive advantage to our business. And finally, after a decade of substantial investment in building the platforms for growth, we'll deliver higher returns on capital to shareholders. This has already begun, and I'm certain that it will continue.

Now these are our immediate management objectives. These are the things that Tesco is focusing on right now. It's not a new strategy. The strategy that served us well will continue. Tesco is and will remain about growth, and we've got multiple opportunities to pursue that growth in the U.K., in Asia, in Europe, in America, in Food, in General Merchandise, in Clothing and in Services. And of course it will be growth that recognizes our responsibilities to the people that we serve and our commitments to sustainability.

So as the fundamental elements of our strategy won't alter, some are evolving. For example, as I've said, to recognize our much stronger focus on Internet Retailing. What I'm going to do now is go through each of these objectives in turn, starting with the U.K.

It was not an easy consumer environment through last year and current conditions are clearly still challenging. Household budgets are under strain from a combination of higher taxes, pressure on incomes and benefits, higher fuel costs and inflation. So it isn't surprising that consumers are cutting back to try and make ends meet.

As we've seen it's already visible in terms of industry growth in both food and non-food retailing. In Food, fallings in the market are muted. There are positives. Inflations is still low as this chart shows, and food price inflation is quite a bit lower than government statistics might suggest.
Although the timing of Easter has got some bearing on the rate of inflation, it's running at more like 1% to 1.5% now, not the mid-single digits that get talked about.

Also, significant numbers of customers are continuing to trade up. In our case that's into Finest, as they look to save money by eating in, by buying better quality to reduce waste. Nevertheless, overall Food growth is unusually low.

And Non-Food has been much more affected. Overall market demand has faltered since about November, particularly in high ticket in non-essential categories. Again though, it isn't uniform. Customers will spend if you've got the things they want to buy, but generally the environment is difficult and sales are hard to come by.

However, this tough macroeconomic environment cannot disguise the fact that our performance has been below par. On almost any metric the U.K. is an outstanding business, market share, sales density, margin, returns, but it's lost a bit of momentum. It hasn't been leading and as today's numbers show it hasn't had a great year by its standards.
Although the background has been unhelpful, it's loss of form has meant that we haven't coped as well as usual with tough trading conditions.

We didn't lose share, but like-for-like was below the market in the second half and profit growth was below our plan. So we've got some work to do. The issues are not structural. I've taken quite a lot of time to study it. It's really all about the detail.

Our basic operating standards are fine. We're delivering a pretty good shopping trip most of the time. Prices are good. We've done a lot of things well such as the new stores which continue to perform very well, Express, which has had an outstanding year, and Clubcard that's driving higher and more stable levels of loyalty. But the core business needs to get back to doing things first for customers and executing better, particularly in some areas of Non-Food such as Electronics and Clothing. We need to drive a faster rate of product innovation, we need to make sure there's more sharpness in our communication to customers. The focus and energy which the new team is bringing is starting to make a difference, and there's a lot more to come.

Turning now to our businesses outside the U.K., I'm going to start with what was not so good, the increased U.S. losses. It's essential that losses come down this year, and so I've spent a lot of time with the Fresh & Easy team and visited stores in every market in recent weeks. As a result, I remain confident that breakeven towards the end of '12, '13 remains a realistic objective.

The key thing for Fresh & Easy, like any retail business, is getting to shop door profitability. After that, it's mostly about scale. To get there in the U.S., we need more customers. The ones who use Fresh & Easy now, well, they love it. We just need more of them. And I can see quite a few things we can do to drive traffic.

One very small example, we're already opening our stores earlier in the morning, we're already selling coffee and pastries from an in-store bakery from 7:00 in the morning, not 8:00. That's normal in America, but we weren't doing it.

There are many, many more things that we can do like that, and I see some promising signs already. Two-year like-for-likes are at 20%, new stores are averaging over $13 a foot. Our best store is now taking over $200,000 a week.
We've got 30 more stores which should cross the line into profitability during the current year, and I'll be updating you on progress in October.

We've also seen important improvements coming through in our campus and our distribution productivity. As a result of integrating Wild Rockets and 2 Sisters, that means we can hit breakeven at 300 stores rather than the 400 in the original plan.

Asia and Europe did very well. They delivered more than two-thirds of the group's growth in trading profit. That was good. But the really important thing for me was we did it at the same time as we had improved like-for-likes and good market share performance.
We haven't had things our own way in all of our markets. The strong headwinds in Ireland and Hungary, two very important markets for us, did slow us down.

Let's take a look at Asia first. Sales and profits grew strongly, despite a slower than expected performance in China in the second half, mainly as a result of the government's economic policy tightening. Korea, Thailand and Malaysia delivered good growth and improved returns. It's no accident either they're all strong, winning businesses, and they've got the potential to push on from here to become much bigger contributors to the Group in the future.

The tough retail environment in Japan has continued to impact our small business there. Obviously, our hearts go out to all those affected by the earthquake and its terrible aftermath. We know we've got work to do with the business there, and we won't commit more capital unless we can clearly see a way to win.

In Central Europe, where it's been hard yards for many years, I believe we're fully really starting to break through to a new level of performance. Poland and Czech – in the past, difficult markets for us – and Slovakia all delivered strong growth. Hungary also grew well, and although the background remains difficult, we're winning market share and coping much better than most with the conditions there.

And there's a lot more to come in Central Europe. Small formats are growing fast. They are profitable. They have low capital intensity. And the Extra format will give our existing hypermarket network even stronger momentum. The eight stores converted so far are seeing uplifts of 16%, and we'll be converting a lot more this year.
Ireland also made progress in the year, and although the background has remained challenging, we've seen good market share growth. Overall, Europe profits grew well with improved margins.

We've got a good international new space pipeline for the year, 8.4 million square feet, giving us sales area growth of 12% overall, 14% in Asia, 9% in Europe and 26% in the U.S. This growth includes a steadier pace, with one strand of our expansion in China. That's the freehold mall development. We'll still push hard on with leasehold hypers, but we've got to recognize that getting permissions for the big freehold projects is not as easy as we thought, and it will take longer than we planned.

To sum up International, we're enjoying increasing success outside the U.K. We've got some really excellent businesses, which I would already define as outstanding. Strong in their markets, growing well, not reliant on the Group to fund their expansion, and returns ahead of the cost of capital.
In some markets, of course, we still have a long way to go on these measures, and mostly that's about building skill and scale, because we're profitable at store level in all but two countries.

Moving on to the third objective, matching our Internet capability with our strength in stores to become a truly multi-channel business wherever we trade. We think the combination of stores and online, of clicks and bricks, can have compelling appeal for customers who want alternatives in terms of both how they shop and how their order fulfillment is achieved. Our existing store network, including Express, can make it really convenient for customers, and we think this will be a strategic advantage for Tesco against the pure play retailers and detailers (14:50).

For Non-Food in particular, it means going well beyond our present range online. Tesco Direct has been a good start, but we aim to go further, with multiple times more range in stock, moving towards more than 100,000 SKUs and our equivalent in the marketplace. Clearly a key part of this will be taking our General Merchandise, Electronics and Clothing offer to the next level, both in stores and online.

But this is not only about the U.K. We're also about to take some important steps outside the U.K. this year. I'll give you a couple of examples. Dotcom grocery will be in Prague in the next few months, and Warsaw in early 2012. A sizeable online Non-Food launch is planned in Korea to complement our growing and profitable Dotcom grocery operation there. So there's more to come.
Whilst investment is needed here, the opportunity enjoys low capital intensity, because it leverages our existing store assets as well as our global and local supply chains and IT infrastructure.

Our fourth objective, delivering on the potential of retailing services, is mostly about the Bank, because as it emerges from the period of migration, it's going to pick up speed and be the main driver of the push to £1 billion of profits from Services.

The Bank has made good progress in some key areas. Our new IT platforms are fully operational and on time, and we'll complete the migration from RBS in the next few months. And as a result, we've been able to start launching our first new products, such as Fixed Rate Saver, you can see here, launched in October. It went really well, pulling in 40% more funds than we anticipated. Our two new Bank customer service centers, they're up and running, having taken on and trained over 1,000 staff.

And the trading performance has been good. The Savings book has grown strongly, up by over £500 million, as has the Loan book with improved margins. The Credit Card business has had an excellent year, with transaction values up 20%. The Motor Insurance book is growing again, having plateaued before acquisition.

The Bank has got momentum on customer growth, the migration is almost complete, and our operating ratios, such as bad debts and product margins, are much improved. The completion of migration will improve our offer and service levels for customers, and it will pave the way for important new products, including mortgages later this year. Clearly, there's a lot to do, but the visibility of the good underlying progress in the Bank will begin to show as we go through the year.

Telecoms has also made good progress, as it broadens its offer into the attractive contract mobile market. Customer numbers are up 24% and Tesco Mobile was the fastest growing network in the U.K. last year. We achieved good growth in contract subscribers, helped by the iPhone 4 launch, and our broadening handset range that we sell through our growing network of Phone Shops. Profit was held back by the initial costs of setting up the Phone Shops and of handset subsidies, but we expect it to pick up this year as the business moves beyond this initial phase of growth.
And the Telecoms story is not only about the U.K. We've now got an MVNO signed for Slovakia. That has already got itself into profit after a very short period of time.

The fifth objective is to add value and competitiveness by applying our Group skill and scale across all of our businesses. In the past we've described this as step change, but it's much bigger and broader than that now, and there are three key elements of it. Firstly, better buying. We now source over £2 billion of Food and Non-Food product at cost through our global and regional sourcing hubs with substantial savings, and these will grow fast. That's because it's really about countries buying more together, using our efficient global supply chains, for example to do more primary distribution and therefore buying for less.

The second element is infrastructure sharing. That's delivering big savings, too. For example, our support center in Bangalore not only supports the U.K. business, but is taking on activities currently done in businesses across the Group from invoice processing to store design. Without it, we'd already have to add back around £100 million a year to our global cost base, and that saving will only get bigger.

The third element of applying Group skill and scale is the operating model. That ensures we don't have to reinvent things as our countries grow. It means we can be quicker and cheaper to market for customers as we build our brand around the world. For example, it costs us just £0.5 million to put Clubcard into a new market today, and installing world-class sales-based ordering only costs £2 million compared with the £100 million it cost to develop in the U.K. These are already material benefits, and with our renewed determination they will rapidly increase.

And finally, our sixth objective is to deliver higher returns for shareholders by capitalizing on the platforms built and the investments made. As you know for well over a decade including through the recession, we've been investing hard in our strategy. We've done a lot of the heavy lifting now, putting the networks down, building the capability, the infrastructure, the scale and the competitiveness.

The investment case for Tesco has also been about growth and returns. That won't change and we see some exciting growth to come, but with those investments maturing, returns and cash generation are also coming through. That's why we're setting a date for our return on capital employed target to be met. We plan to hit 14.6% return on capital employed by the 2014, '15 financial year.

With well over £20 billion of capital employed in the group, on a good current level of return by industry standards, this is a substantial increase and it's happening now. Laurie will talk about that in more detail very shortly.

Linked to this, we're not only aiming to align more closely performance and reward around returns in the board room, we're also going to take a similar approach for the whole senior management team, which today is over 500 strong.

So, to sum up, we've got six clear objectives. They're about continuing to drive forward growth, about sharp execution and about a very strong focus on delivering increased returns for shareholders now and in the future. But in closing I wanted to say a few things about what shareholders should expect from me.

The first thing, and for those of you who know me, this won't be altogether new, is more focus, more energy, more drive and determination. That's the way I like Tesco to work. I like us to be in shops. I like us to be close to customers. I like us to be close to colleagues.

The second is that I aim to be open and willing to engage, including discussing what's not so good about our performance as well as the many good things that are going on. Tesco's success is all about people, about serving customers well and gaining the loyalty and the commitments of our staff.

We've also put communities at the heart of what we do and have established a leadership role on sustainability, particular – particularly in the area of climate change. Shareholders can only benefit if we keep our unrelenting focus on all these things: our customers, our colleagues, the communities we serve.

We built a great business and we're really excited about the future. In the end of course, it's all about performance. That's what matters and that's what we intend to deliver. Thank you for listening. I'll now hand over to Laurie.
Thank you, Phil, and good morning, everyone.

So despite a difficult economic environment in a number of our markets we've delivered a strong Group performance, double-digit profit growth, a strengthened balance sheet and an increased return on capital employed. Here's a summary of our group performance: Group sales were £68 billion, up 8.1%. Group trading profit rose by 7.8% and underlying profits grew by 12.3%.

Before property profits, underlying profits also grew by 12%. Consistent with our policy of growing dividends broadly in line with diluted underlying EPS, the full year dividend is 14.46 pence, up 10.8% on a constant tax rate basis. Net debt has reduced by more than the £1 billion in the year to £6.8 billion, that's beating our target by £200 million. And return on capital employed has increased from 12.1% to 12.9%.

I'd like to highlight some of the important areas of this year's performance, what's not so good and what's good, starting with the income statement. In the U.K. we achieved a respectable profit performance in challenging conditions. Sales growth was slower than the historical trend, principally due to the pressure on consumers from petrol prices, inflation more generally, and taxes. We estimate that for the typical family the combined effect is about £18 a week, or the equivalent of a 7% rise in the basic rate of tax.

Moving to the U.K. profit performance, we maintained a stable margin despite the higher rents from sale and leasebacks and the additional investment in Clubcard points. Stripping out the impact of the increased rents, our U.K. profits grew by 6.4%, significantly ahead of sales.

We delivered a strong performance in Asia; sales grew by 22% and profits grew by 30%. Margins strengthened by 35 basis points to 5.6% and with increases in Thailand, Malaysia and Korea. The margin for Asia is now back to its pre-recession level. The acquired Homever stores delivered a 6.5% margin and this is just two years after they were loss making at acquisition.

In China we performed well but we didn't reach breakeven in the second half. This was due to the impact on customers from the government's tightening economic policy, high cost inflation and our store rollout being slower than planned. Of course we are planning to improve on this performance in the coming year.

In Europe sales and profits grew at their fastest rate for a number of years. We made significant market share gains and margins improved to 5.7%. The benefits of our continued investment through the downturn are starting to bear fruit.

In addition, a lot of good work has started on our regional scale initiatives, such as joint buying, harmonizing of seasonal promotions and the rollout of our Extra format. In Hungary, we've been subject to a retrospective crisis tax of £32 million. The European Commission is investigating the legality of the tax because of its discriminatory impact; however, as it currently stands, we're due to pay a similar amount in the next two years.

In the U.S. we had previously guided that losses had plateaued, but they, in fact, they increased by £16 million at constant exchange rates. Let me explain why. As you can see from this chart, the strong like-for-like margin performance were offset by the impact of new stores. This represents about 40% of the estate. The rise in losses, however, was primarily caused by the short-term additional integration costs from the acquisition of our two key fresh suppliers. There were many positives in Fresh & Easy's performance, as Phil touched on. Like-for-like sales were consistently strong through the year, and in Q4 we had a two-year like-for-like of 20%, so real progress. Many of our financial and operational metrics are improving, including losses per week per store, which are coming down steadily.

Turning to the Bank, we had a strong trading performance with good growth in customer numbers. For example, Credit Cards were up 11%, Loans up 17% and Motor Insurance up 8%. Income has benefited from continued improvement in interest margins, larger customer balances and a 20% growth in credit card spend. We've been able to absorb the higher running costs during migration phase, and going forward, our cost/income ratio will improve.

Our bad debt charge was 26% lower despite growth in the Loan books, so that's extremely encouraging. The stronger underlying performance has resulted in the release of provisions created under acquisition accounting, specifically £155 million of fair value and £50 million of payment protection insurance. Reflecting an industry-wide trend of higher bodily injury claims, we've increased our provisions by £99 million.

As you can see from the chart, after stripping away the various adjustments, the baseline profitability of the Bank was up 20% while absorbing the impact of our migration costs. In 2011 and '12, the headline trading profit number will not increase much as the fair value provisions release has materially unwound. But we are expecting a good improvement in the base line profitability.

During the course of the year, the Bank's capital position strengthened, moving its risk/asset ratio from 12.8% to 13.5% and its core Tier 1 ratio from 12.9% to 15.9%. This reflects our prudent approach to the Bank's balance sheet, and a steady preparation for mortgage launch.

Turning now to the Group balance sheet, net debt reduced by £1.1 billion to £6.8 billion and CapEx was £3.7 billion, which was 5.5% to sales. Going forward we expect to maintain CapEx in the range of 5% to 5.5% while maintaining our freehold mix at around 70%. The maturity of our investments in Asia and Europe, coupled with our improving capital efficiency, is key to achieving this lower rate.

Our cash flow from operations was strong once again. The U.K. generated £3.6 billion versus £1.7 billion of cash CapEx. Although CapEx for our International business was slightly greater than our operating cash flow, we were cash flow positive in Korea, Ireland, Thailand and the Czech Republic.

With our strong operational cash flow and our growing property divestment program, net debt is set to fall further in the coming years. However, as we have a balance sheet, a balance of funding from corporate debt and leases, it's important to look at our liabilities holistically. So for this reason, I'll be focusing more on fixed charge cover, which we are targeting to be between 4 and 4.5 times. As you can also see from the chart, our total net indebtedness has already improved to the levels of 2008, and we are targeting this to improve further to 2.5 times.

Our property strategy is an integral part of how we retail, and at our interims, we promised to update you on this. But before I get into the detail, I'd like to set out the overall philosophy. Tesco's property activities have one principal objective, to ensure that we have the best properties from which to retail. As a result, we also create long-term shareholder value from property development and management. This year we sold £1.9 billion of assets at sub-5% yields, and this now completes the five-year program set out in 2006. In summary, this program has delivered in excess of £5 billion of proceeds, £1.3 billion worth of underlying profits and funded a 1.1 billion share buyback.

I think the best way to describe our strategy going forward is in the context of a couple of questions. First, is the profit from the sale of property a real and sustainable profit stream? And second, if it is real, what would be a reasonable expectation of the level of profits a property owner, such as ourselves, should deliver?

Looking at the first question, the only profit we intend to release is the value we add when we develop a site into a completed store that has a vacant possession value higher than its net book value. There's no way to release this value except through the sale of the property, as it's effectively trapped. This is shown in the chart in green. As long as we are creating as much development profit as we are releasing, then it will be sustainable. And any other profit through rental inflation or Tesco's covenant, shown here in yellow bars, would get to shareholders through trading profit.

In terms of the amount of profit we intend to release, we are targeting £250 million to £350 million per year and these next few charts illustrate why this kind of figure makes sense. First, property companies typically earn about 8% on assets and that's on the market value of our properties, this would equate to about £2.5 billion of income a year, shown here as the blue bar on the left.

If Tesco's freehold stores were rented at the market rental yields this would return about £2.1 billion, which would leave a sum, which is – sorry – is the sum in the red bars on the chart, and this leaves about £400 million to be earned from development activities.

A second approach is to look at our own empirical experience as a developer. As with any portfolio there's a range of performance, but looking back over the last decade, when we compare the market value of a completed site with the capital invested we've typically created a 10% uplift on U.K. projects and mid-teen uplifts internationally. And based on our current annual investment in land and building of around £2.5 billion pounds, a 10% to 15% uplift would mean that in a typical year we'll generate between £250 million and £400 million of value as a developer.

So bringing these two methodologies together, as shown on this new chart, it's our judgment that £250 million to £350 million is an appropriate and sustainable target, and that's what you should expect from us going forward. It's a little less than recent history, but it won't have an adverse effect on earnings growth or dividends, and that's because the reduction will be gradual and profit growth in the rest of the Group will be strong. We expect to divest just over £1 billion pounds per year to generate this level of profits, and clearly if we're divesting £1 billion pounds while investing £2.5 billion pounds in stores and land, this is a sustainable strategy and the asset base will continue to grow. With a steady level of divestment and property profit, we expect rent as a proportion of the Group EBITDA to remain broadly constant.

In our Asia and Europe business we have sizeable mall portfolios, which are important contributors obviously to country profitability. However, mall income grows at a slower rate and produces lower returns than a Tesco Hyper. Some of our malls have been fully developed, but many have significant opportunity for redevelopment, for example, to convert a small strip of shops alongside a hypermarket into a large mall. This chart shows an example of a prospective development in Asia and the expected value creation from the project. The plan is to expand the mall from 170,000 square feet to 600,000 square feet. The cost of the redevelopment is expected to be about £50 million, but the increase in market value will be about £100 million. Importantly, this results in a far superior shopping experience for our customers.

In the future you'll see us selling some of our fully developed malls and leasing back the hypermarket. We'll then use the proceeds created to redevelop some of our smaller strip malls, but importantly it will always be our objective to manage our malls.

The final subject I'd like to discuss is returns, and at over 12%, Tesco's return on capital is already good by industry standards. I'm pleased to say that we've made good progress in the last year, increasing our ROCE from 12.1% to 12.9% and on our way to our 14.6% target. As you can see from this chart, most of the step up came from operational improvements in the form of strong profit growth and improved working capital, and about 40 basis points came from greater capital efficiency as a result of the sale and leaseback program. To demonstrate our commitment to the increased focus on returns, we'd like to provide more clarity on both the shape and timeframes for the improvements going forward. We plan to reach our 14.6% by 2014, '15. As this chart shows, our profit growth starts to outweigh our capital growth materially as businesses become more mature and our margins improve.

The next slide shows the current ROCE of each part of our business. Our largest businesses, the U.K., Korea, Ireland, Thailand, Hungary and the Bank, which combined represent three-quarters of the group's capital employed, are achieving good returns already. In Poland, Slovakia, Czech, Malaysia, the infrastructure's broadly complete, we have leading market positions, and our weighting of immature capital will fall. Now this cohort will be around about 10% ROCE by 2014, '15.

And finally, we have our emerging businesses, and these are building infrastructure, have a high proportion of immature capital, and are not yet profitable. Now as a growth business, we'll always have some immature capital, but we expect this cohort to be returning to (38:44) the Group's WACC within the next four years. So what's currently a significant drag on the Group today, will start to diminish.

The U.K. will also contribute. Returns have made steady progress in recent history. Sales densities have held up well and the capital cost per square foot has fallen and margins have risen. And going forward, we will see more of the same but with particular emphasis on reduced WIP and the growth in Retail Services.

So to sum up, we've delivered steady profit growth in the U.K., and outstanding growth in Asia and Europe. We're making progress in China and the U.S., but clearly we've got more to do. We're in the last few months of the migration phase in the Bank and strong underlying profits are coming through. We have an excellent property portfolio that will release sustainable profits. And finally, with strong cash flow, good capital discipline, we'll be strengthening our balance sheet and delivering an improving return on capital employed.
Thank you. We will now take questions.

Good. Thank you, Laurie. We'll just open it up for questions, right? There are microphones around. So if you put your hand up and if just say where you're from, that would always be helpful. Let's start with Andrew. Sorry, Philip.

Yeah, hi. Andrew Kasoulis, Credit Suisse. Phil, just sort of three things that you didn't touch on, just to get a sense of where you are at the start of your tenure. Views on double Clubcard points, please. Do you think you'll keep them? Secondly, you spoke a lot about base infrastructure, do you think you'll be entering any more countries over the next few years? I know you've touched on, talked about Indonesia in the past, for example. And thirdly, can you give us a bit more detail on what you're thinking about linking a broader management base to returns. Will you keep the same measure of return on capital for example and link a bigger pool of people to that current return on capital or will you change your definition of return on capital?

Well I'll answer them in reverse order, because the easy one was at the end and the more difficult one was in the middle or the beginning. Yeah. We'll keep the same definition of return on capital employed. We want to incentivize the top 500 to deliver their share of the returns growth as much as their share of the top line and the profit growth and we haven't done that quite as systematically. So that's what we'll be doing. And 500 managers there, broadly speaking, in all of our businesses, the top couple of levels.

New markets, always tempting. I think we recognize that at least for a year or two we should focus on what we're doing and demonstrate that we can make good progress in each element of our strategy and against our six objectives.
